title: A 24 Week, Prospective, Randomized, Parallel-group, Double-blind, Multi-center Study (ENA713DUS44) Comparing the Effects of Rivastigmine Patch 15 cm^2 vs. Rivastigmine Patch 5 cm^2 on ACTivities of Daily Living and CognitION in Patients With Severe Dementia of the Alzheimer's Type (ACTION) and a 24-week Open-label Extension to Study ENA713DUS44
description_brief: The core study assessed the efficacy of a higher dose of rivastigmine 13.3 mg/24 h transdermally (15 cm\^2 patch) compared to a lower dose of the rivastigmine 4.6 mg/24 h transdermally (5 cm\^2 patch) in patients with Severe Dementia of the Alzheimer's Type in a 24-week study. The extension study obtained additional safety and efficacy data, as well as provided the higher dose rivastigmine patch to all patients who completed the core study for an additional 24 weeks.

participantFlowModule.preAssignmentDetails: One patient in each treatment group in the core study and one patient in the treatment group in the extension study did not receive study medication; they were not included in the safety set.

groups.description: Patients received rivastigmine 4.6 mg/24 h (5 cm\^2).

achievements.comment: 397 of the 463 patients who completed the core study entered the extension study.
No patients received this treatment in the extension study.

groups.title: Core Study: Rivastigmine 13.3 mg/24 h Transdermal Patch
groups.description: Patients received rivastigmine 13.3 mg/24 h (15 cm\^2).

groups.title: Core Study: Rivastigmine 4.6 mg/24 h Transdermal Patch
groups.description: Patients received rivastigmine 4.6 mg/24 h (5 cm\^2).

outcomeMeasures.title: Core Study: Change From Baseline in the Alzheimer's Disease Cooperative Study-Activities of Daily Living-Severe Impairment Version (ADCS-ADL-SIV) Score at Week 24
outcomeMeasures.description: The ADCS-ADL-SIV is designed to assess the patient's performance of both basic and instrumental activities of daily living such as those necessary for personal care, communicating and interacting with other people, maintaining a household, conducting hobbies and interests, and making judgments and decisions. For each of the 19 questions in the ADCS-ADL-SIV, there was either a forced choice of best response or a "yes" or "no" question with additional sub-questions. Responses for each item were obtained from the caregiver through an interview. Higher numbered scores and answers of "yes" reflected a more self-sufficient individual. The total score was calculated as the sum of all items and sub-questions and ranged from 0 to 54. A higher total score represented a higher functioning patient. A positive change score indicates improvement.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Modified full analysis set: All randomized patients who received at least 1 dose of study medication and had at least 1 post-baseline measurement of the co-primary efficacy variables. Only patients with available data were included in the analysis.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Baseline of the core study to Week 24 of the core study

outcomeMeasures.title: Core Study: Change From Baseline in the Severity Impairment Battery (SIB) Score at Week 24
outcomeMeasures.description: The SIB is a 40-item scale developed for the evaluation of the severity of cognitive dysfunction in more advanced Alzheimer Disease patients. The domains assessed included social interaction, memory, language, attention, orientation, praxis, visuo-spatial ability, construction, and orienting to name. The items of the SIB were developed as simple 1-step commands which are presented by a trained rater with gestural cues and repeated if necessary. The SIB was scored from 0 to 100, with higher scores reflecting higher levels of cognitive ability. A positive change score indicates improvement.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Modified full analysis set: All randomized patients who received at least 1 dose of study medication and had at least 1 post-baseline measurement of the co-primary efficacy variables. Only patients with available data were included in the analysis.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Baseline of the core study to Week 24 of the core study

outcomeMeasures.title: Core Study: Alzheimer's Disease Cooperative Study-Clinical Global Impression of Change (ADCS-CGIC) Score at Week 24
outcomeMeasures.description: The ADCS-CGIC assesses the clinical meaningfulness of a treatment based on the clinician's rating of change. The rating is provided by a trained clinician or psychometrician blinded to the patient's treatment. The rater interviewed the patient and caregiver separately at Baseline using a worksheet that provided space for notes and comments. At baseline, raters had access to all of the patient's available records and evaluations. The rater used a similar worksheet at follow-up visits, and referred to the baseline worksheet prior to making a rating of change. The worksheets were divided into 3 domains: mental/cognitive state, behavior, and functioning. Change ratings were based on a 7-point scale: Marked (1), moderate (2), and minimal improvement (3), no change (4), and marked (5), moderate (6), and minimal worsening (7). The percentage of patients in each of the 7 categories is reported.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Modified full analysis set: All randomized patients who received at least 1 dose of study medication and had at least 1 post-baseline measurement of the co-primary efficacy variables. Only patients with available data were included in the analysis.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Baseline of the core study to Week 24 of the core study

outcomeMeasures.title: Core Study: Change From Baseline in the Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI-12) Score at Week 24
outcomeMeasures.description: The NPI-12 assesses a wide range of behaviors encountered in patients with dementia to provide a means of distinguishing the frequency and severity of behavioral changes over time. Ten behavioral and 2 neurovegetative domains were evaluated in an interview with the caregiver given by a mental health professional. The scale included both frequency and severity ratings of each domain as well as a composite domain score (frequency x severity). The sum of the composite scores for the 12 domains yielded the NPI-12 total score. The NPI-12 was scored from 0 to 144, with lower scores reflecting improvement in psychiatric behavior. A negative change score indicates improvement.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Modified full analysis set: All randomized patients who received at least 1 dose of study medication and had at least 1 post-baseline measurement of the co-primary efficacy variables. Only patients with available data were included in the analysis.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Baseline of the core study to Week 24 of the core study

The total score was calculated as the sum of all items and sub-questions and ranged from 0 to 54. A higher total score represented a higher functioning patient. A positive change score indicates improvement.

adverseEventsModule.timeFrame: Adverse events were reported from randomization in the core study through the end of the extension study (48 weeks).
adverseEventsModule.description: Safety set: All patients who received at least 1 dose of study medication and had at least 1 safety assessment after baseline. One patient in each treatment group did not receive study medication and were not included in the safety set.

certainAgreement.otherDetails: The terms and conditions of Novartis' agreements with its investigators may vary. However, Novartis does not prohibit any investigator from publishing. Any publications from a single-site are postponed until the publication of the pooled data (ie, data from all sites) in the clinical trial.

drug: rivastigmine (Exelon) transdermal patch 13.3 mg/24 h (15 cm^2) and 4.6 mg/24 h (5 cm^2)
explanation_target: Reason: The trial compares two doses of rivastigmine delivered by transdermal patch in patients with severe Alzheimer’s disease, with co‑primary outcomes of activities of daily living and cognition—indicating the aim is symptomatic cognitive/functional improvement rather than modifying underlying pathology. citeturn0search1turn0search3.

Act (extraction and mechanism): Rivastigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor (inhibits acetylcholinesterase and butyrylcholinesterase) that increases brain acetylcholine to improve cognitive function; it is a symptomatic cognitive enhancer and is not considered disease‑modifying. The study tested 13.3 mg/24 h vs 4.6 mg/24 h patches for 24 weeks (with a 24‑week open‑label extension). citeturn1search0turn0search1.

Reflect (classification rationale): Given the intervention (a small‑molecule cholinesterase inhibitor) and the trial endpoints (cognition and ADLs), the appropriate category is Cognitive enhancer (category 3). The literature and product labeling describe rivastigmine as symptomatic therapy for cognition in Alzheimer’s disease rather than a biologic targeting amyloid/tau or a disease‑modifying small molecule. citeturn0search2turn0search4.

Web search results used (key sources): ACTION trial design and aims (PubMed abstract). citeturn0search1; Neurology/AAN results reporting benefit of 13.3 vs 4.6 mg/24h on ADL and cognition. citeturn0search3; Novartis / Exelon Patch label/indication (product information and approval for use in Alzheimer’s dementia). citeturn0search2turn0search0; Mechanism and pharmacology (StatPearls / prescribing information: rivastigmine inhibits AChE and BuChE, enhances cholinergic function). citeturn1search0turn1search2; Cochrane review summarizing symptomatic benefit of rivastigmine in AD. citeturn0search4.
explanation_agent: Reason: The trial tests rivastigmine transdermal patches (higher vs lower dose) to improve cognition and activities of daily living in severe Alzheimer’s disease, indicating a symptomatic strategy focused on augmenting cholinergic neurotransmission rather than modifying amyloid/tau pathology. citeturn0search1turn0search0

Act (extraction and mechanism): The investigational product is rivastigmine (Exelon) transdermal patch 13.3 mg/24 h (15 cm^2) versus 4.6 mg/24 h (5 cm^2). Rivastigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor that reversibly inhibits acetylcholinesterase (AChE) and butyrylcholinesterase (BuChE), increasing synaptic acetylcholine to improve cognitive function — i.e., it modulates neurotransmitter signaling. citeturn0search2turn1search0turn1search6

Reflect: Mapping to CADRO, this mechanism best fits D) Neurotransmitter Receptors because the drug acts by enhancing cholinergic neurotransmission (through inhibition of cholinesterase enzymes), a neurotransmitter-system–directed symptomatic approach rather than a disease‑modifying target (amyloid, tau, inflammation, etc.). The trial endpoints (cognition and ADLs) and the approved/supported indication further confirm a symptomatic neurotransmitter-based classification. citeturn0search1turn0search0

Web search results used (key sources): ACTION trial publication (PubMed). citeturn0search1; Novartis/Exelon patch FDA approval / media release describing the ACTION study and dose comparison. citeturn0search0; ClinicalTrials.gov / trial registry listing (NCT00948766) with ENA713DUS44 details. citeturn0search2; Rivastigmine mechanism and pharmacology (StatPearls). citeturn1search0; Review of rivastigmine dual AChE/BuChE inhibition and clinical role. citeturn1search6
